data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
Fu-Shan is a Force affinity Legendary Champion in the Lizardmen faction that is very versatile as he can be used in almost all areas of the game. He is an ATK based champion with good damage multipliers allowing him to hit hard. He has a high chance to place 60% Decrease Defense on multiple targets and can AOE stun. His A1 hits hard and Fu-Shan has a 25% chance to perform his A1 again that stacks continuously allowing him to use A1 on a target multiple times if you’re lucky. This can rack up a ton of damage over time. He also has an extremely useful 24% Speed Aura for all battles. 

If you are using him, booking him is highly recommended as it improves his performance tremendously. Both his abilities can be lowered to 3 turns CD, the debuff chance and damage increases significantly with books.

The first page of this guide will focus on Fu-Shan in an Unkillable Clan Boss team and the following pages will showcase him in Regular dungeon teams, a standard CA CB team, Solo Dragon 20, Arena, and Faction War with different builds. If you are a mid-game player and don't have Unkillable CB team check them out first.

For a Clan Boss unkillable team Offense Tree is the golden rule. The standard Crit Rate, Crit Damage, damage increasing Masteries down to T6 Warmaster is selected for the usual CB champions in the Offense Tree. For the other tree, the choice depends on the gear and the set you use on him. 

In this guide, Retaliation set is used that gives him a chance to counterattack so the Support tree was chosen. The accuracy Masteries are selected, avoiding the TM boosting masteries, down to Lore of Steel for more stats and the T5 Sniper mastery to increase the chance to place Decrease Defense and Master Hexer to improve the Decrease Defense debuff duration. 

If you are unable to gear Fu-shan in a Retaliation set, Defense Tree is recommended instead with the T5 Retribution Mastery for a chance to counterattack.
data.label: Masteries

data.desc:
In an Unkillable Team (without a Counterattack champion), Retaliation Set on Fu-shan is highly recommended. Most of his damage comes from his A1 and giving him the opportunity to use his A1 as much as possible improves his damage tremendously. 

The Retaliation set synergizes extremely well as the set gives a 35% chance to counterattack when hit and it works with EACH hit, so when the CB does his AOE with multiple hits (i.e on affinity, his AOE does 2 hits and 4 hits respectively), each of those hits can trigger the CA but you can still only CA once. You can use any other secondary set to meet your needed stats but I highly recommend Cruel set to optimized damage.

The stats to aim for are Crit Rate, Crit Damage, Attack, Accuracy and the speed to match your speedtune. Note that Fu-shan has a 24% all battle Speed Aura which works on Clan Boss. This means that if you use Fu-shan as the lead, you can reduce the speed requirement of your entire CB team which allows you to gear them much better for damage. Also note that the aura only affects the base speed stat, not the total.

Glove: Crit Damage %
Chest: Attack %
Boots: Attack %
Ring: Attack
Amulet: Crit Damage
Banner: Attack/Accuracy
data.label: Gear and stats

data.desc:
This is an Unkillable UNM team that is built specifically to take advantage of Fu-shan’s Speed Aura. Every champion has speeds that are lower that the required speed on their stat page, but in battle with the Speed aura, they are able to hit the required speed.

The speed settings used for this team are:

196 ME (219 after speed aura)
191 ME (214 after speed aura)
149 Kreela (172 after speed aura)
148 Longbeard (171 after speed aura)
134 Fu-shan (159 after speed aura)

The is a team combination that takes advantage of Fu-shan and Kreela that provide Speed Aura and increase Crit Rate buff for the team. This allows everyone in this team to be built much better with the reduced stat requirement (Less speed and only 70% crit rate). This team has Decrease Defense from Fu-shan, Weaken from Longbeard, and double ally attack to take advantage of everyone’s hard hitting A1, especially Fu-shan’s. Two Maneaters provide permanent Block Debuffs and Unkillable

This video showcases this team in action and comfortably hitting 1 Key in Ultra Nightmare CB

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QCIkogm6xw4

You can find more information about the double Maneater unkillable variations here https://www.deadwoodjedi.com/speed-tunes-4/Easy-Double-Maneater

On the next page we will explore how Fu-shan performs in Dungeons
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
The Fu-Shan mastiries you've seen on the previous page for the Unkillable CB team can be used for dungeons and general purpose as well. He can perform his duties just as well in that type of content, although better results can be achieved by having different types of equipment.

If you are using him, booking him is highly recommended as it improves his performance tremendously. Both his abilities can be lowered to 3 turns CD, the debuff chance and damage increases significantly with books.

The standard Crit Rate, Crit Damage, damage increasing Masteries down to T6 Warmaster is selected for the usual CB champions in the Offense Tree. If you are using him outside of Clan Boss you can also opt in for Flawless Execution or Helmsmasher if your Crit Rate and Crit Damage are sufficient (100% and 220%+ respectively).

The accuracy Masteries are selected, avoiding the TM boosting masteries, down to Lore of Steel for more stats and the T5 Sniper mastery to increase the chance to place Decrease Defense and Master Hexer to improve the Decrease Defense debuff duration. Defense Tree can be picked if your Fu-Shan doesn't survive in the dungeons. Fu-Shan is flexible in terms of masteries and gear for this type of content.

Another general build that saw some use should be mentioned. Fu-Shan in a stun set with Fearsome Presence was an option that is used rarely. However, generally it seems this was too much focus on stuns and this type of build has faded out, especially with the prevalence of block debuffs in the Platinum Arena metagame and the lack of need for this in the dungeons.
data.label: Masteries

data.desc:
For a general PVE Dungeon FW build, gear sets are not very important. Any sets can be used as long as you meet the stat requirement but the best-in-slot sets are Savage and Cruel. 

You want to build Fu-shan as close as possible to 4k Attack, 100% Crit Rate, 220+ Accuracy, 200%+ Crit Damage and 200+ Speed. 

Glove: Crit Damage/Crit Rate
Chest: Attack %
Boots: Speed 
Ring: Attack
Amulet: Crit Damage
Banner: Attack/Accuracy
data.label: Gear and stats

data.desc:
Dragon 20

Fu-shan is an incredibly strong champion for Dungeon progression. He offers DPS to nuke the waves, control with his AOE stuns, and can place Decrease Defense as a backup. Additionally, he has the speed aura that boosts your entire team’s speed. 

The video shows an example of a simple Dragon 20 team with Gorgorab for Increase Attack buff, Scyl for healing and CC, Zargala for Decrease Defense, Kael for Poisons against the Dragon and Fushan as DPS, stun control, and backup Decrease Defense. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ziIhNwhoW6I

Notice how Fu-shan proc-ed multiple A1s against the Dragon at the end and did a ton of damage to finish it off.
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
For a standard Clan Boss team, Fu-shan needs to be built differently with different masteries. 

The first mastery tree is the usual suspect - the Offense Tree. The standard Crit Rate, Crit Damage, damage increasing Masteries down to T6 Warmaster is selected. 

For the second tree, Defense tree is recommended instead of support for more survivability since lasting longer is much more important in standard CB teams. The key masteries to take are Blastproof and Delayed Death for damage mitigation and the Retribution and Deterrence T5 Mastery for counterattack.
data.label: Masteries

data.desc:
Lifesteal set is a must for non-unkillable teams unless you have a Leech in the team. 

Prioritize building Fu-shan with Defense rather than Attack. Ideally want at least 3000 Defense for UNM, 2500 for NM with enough speed to match your CB speed tune. If you need him to place Decrease Defense, then 220-250 accuracy is needed. Aim for 100% Crit Rate and as much Attack and Crit Damage as possible after you hit the necessary Def, Speed, and accuracy numbers (if you need it). 

Note that all of Fu-shan's damage are from his raw hits, he has no poisons, so he still needs Attack to actually deal damage. At least 3500 attack is recommended for Fu-shan to have an impact. You can then use any 2-piece set to achieve the desired stat. Speed Offense, Cruel, etc.

Since Defense is more important, I do not recommend using his Speed Aura as your lead (unless you have no other options), and use a Defense Aura instead. This means you need to build the necessary speed for your entire team.

Chest: Def %
Boots: Speed / Def %
Ring: Defense

data.desc:
The video below shows an example of a Standard Counterattack Clan Boss team with Fu-Shan as the a DPS without any poisoner. The run unfortunately ended early due to Sepulcher missing the Decrease Attack Debuff on the Clan Boss. 

As you can see, Fu-shan did almost as much damage as Rhazin even though he had to be built defensively. It is worth noting that using an Attack-based champion like Fu-shan for a standard Clan Boss team is not ideal. Especially for Fu-shan all of his damage comes from his raw hits, so it is very difficult to build him defensively while maintaining a relevant enough attack to do damage. However, this team still comfortably hit the 3 Key UNM threshold despite ending early. 

Ultra-Nightmare CB: https://youtu.be/2NRvNuPoLjM

The champions used and their speeds are as follow:

Sepulcher Sentinel 227 – Atk Down debuff, Block Debuffs block Stun
Kreela 174 – Increase Attack, Increase Crit Rate, Ally Attack
Rhazin 175 –Decrease Def, Weaken, Ally Attack
Fu-shan 173 –DPS
Skullcrusher 171 – Counterattack, Ally Protection
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
Fu-shan can be a strong Arena Nuker with his solid damage multipliers, multi-hit AOE that is useful against Rotos, and may even stun the enemy. Overall he has potential for Gold IV and low Platinum. He gets outclassed by other pure damage dealers and due to the prevalence of block debuffs at the top.

For Arena the Offense and Defense Tree masteries are recommended. In the Offense tree, take the Crit Rate, Crit Damage, Arena damage increasing masteries like Heart of Glory, Ruthless Ambush, and Opportunist since he can place stuns down to T6 Helmsmasher for a chance to ignore Defense. 

In the Defense tree, Defiant is selected to take Improved Parry to reduce critical hits, into Bloodthirst, Delayed Death, and Harvest Despair since he can stun. Both of the Counterattack masteries are selected for T5.
data.label: Masteries

data.desc:
The best set for Arena nukers are Savage and Cruel. 

Fu-shan needs 100% Crit Rate with as much Attack and Crit Damage as possible with enough speed to match your team so your turn sequence doesn't get cut into. 

Accuracy is not necessary but can be useful as stuns are a very strong debuff to apply to your opponent and can just win you the match. 

Ideally at least 4k Attack, 100% Crit Rate, 200%+ Crit Damage, and 200+ Speed are watned. Accuracy of 200+ should be enough to stun most TM boosters, Debuffers, or Nukers since those champions are not usually built with high resistance but 200 Accuracy is definitely not enough against high resistance teams. Remember that his main purpose is to nuke, stunning the enemy is secondary and a nice bonus if it happens.

Glove: Crit Damage
Chest: Attack %
Boots: Speed 
Ring: Attack
Amulet: Crit Damage
Banner: Attack
data.label: Gear and stats

data.desc:
Fu-shan can be a decent Arena Nuker if you don’t have any dedicated Arena Nuker.

He has solid damage multipliers, multi-hit AOE that is needed against Rotos who has a passive that prevents him from taking more than 50% of his HP in damage per hit and may even stun the enemies. 

Fu-Shan also has a 24% speed aura that can be used in Arena especially if you don’t have an Arbiter yet. 

The video showcases a standard Arena team with 

Arbiter for TM Boost and Increase Attack
Lyssandra for a second TM Boost
Madame Serris to remove buffs and place Decrease Defense
Fu-shan to nuke in Gold 4 Arena. 

Since Fu-shan is Force Affinity, you have to watch out when facing Duchess Lilitu. There is a significant chance of weak hitting her due to negative affinity and she lowers the AOE damage you do. If you fail to kill her, she can revive her team and quickly turn the fight against you.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nIsHDDpeL0k
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
Another unique use for Fu-shan is that he can built to Solo Dragon 20. Fu-shan is one of the few champions in the game that can do so efficiently. The solo Dragon 20 build is slightly different from the previous builds shown in this guide and the following masteries are crucial to solo Dragon 20:

In the Offense tree, take the standard Crit Rate, Crit Damage masteries and Grim Resolve since Fu-shan will always be below 50% health when he attacks. Then take all the left most Offense Masteries to increase damage all the way down to T6 Warmaster. Lifedrinker is important to lifesteal, Wrath of the Slain to increase damage when your food dies, and Killstreak to increase damage as he kills the mobs.

Defense Tree is very important to take. The damage mitigation masteries in Blastproof and Delayed Death are important to survive the Dragon long enough to kill it. Resurgent gives you a chance to remove the stuns placed and Retribution for a chance to counterattack.
data.label: Masteries

data.desc:
Lifesteal set is a must to solo Dragon 20. This build can be quite difficult to make as it requires quite a lot of stats and good gear to achieve. 

You need to first achieve at least 260+ Resistance to reliably resist all debuffs, 220+ Accuracy to place debuffs, and 200+ speed to go two turns against the mob and Dragon. 

Aim for at least 3.5k Attack, 85% Crit rate (since he is force affinity and gains bonus 15% crit rate against magic affinity enemies), and 200%+ Crit damage. You still need to do enough damage to kill the Dragon in time before it ramps up and one-shots you. These numbers are sufficient to achieve stable runs. You can use any other sets for your final two-piece to achieve the needed stats.

Glove: Crit Damage
Chest: Resistance/Accuracy
Boots: Speed 
Ring: Attack
Amulet: Crit Damage
Banner: Resistance/Accuracy
data.label: Gear and stats

data.desc:
The video belows shows a Fu-shan Solo Dragon 20 run with 4 food. The run will start out slow as Fu-Shan needs the food to die and kill the mobs to gain additional damage from Wrath of the Slain and Killstreak mastery. You can then see Fu-Shan AOE nuking the waves while controlling them with his stuns. 

On the Dragon fight, it is important to note that Fu-shan can only survive 4 of the Dragon Big Scorch ability (The charge up breath). He will die from the 5th Scorch. If you are unable to kill it by then, it means that Fu-shan needs more damage. This build specifically will always kill the Dragon when he charges up for the fifth Scorch for a reliable 2.5 minute run as shown in this video.

https://youtu.be/RpOwHBEQY-8
data.label: Notes:

title: Fu-Shan Late Game+ Guide Dungeon Runs

data.desc:
Fire Knight 20

Fu-shan a strong champion for Fire Knight. 

He can be part of end-game sub 1 min Fire Knight 20 runs. 

This video show that team which includes 

Gorgorab for Increase Attack and TM boost
Stag Knight for Decrease Def, Decrease Attack and Decrease Speed.
x2 CH for their famous utility of multi-hit to break the shield and Heartseeker for the Max Hp nuke
Fu-shan for AOE wave clear, multi-hit A3 to break the shield and place Decrease Def, and A1 that occasionally does a ton of DPS against the boss or break the shield.

Additionally, he has the speed aura that boosts your entire team’s speed.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wsoSik3OHm4
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
Spider 19

Due to negative affinity, Fu-shan cannot be reliably used in Spider 20. However, he is quite effective in helping you clear Spider 19 for your mission. He is the counterpart to Scyl for Spider 19. Since Scyl is bad affinity here, her AOE stuns is not reliable but Fu-shan has the same AOE stun ability to control the spiderlings. 

He also provides a Speed Aura and Decrease Def (it is random, but the first hit always targets the boss). He also deals significant amount of damage to kill of the spiderlings in a couple of AOEs.

The video below shows an example of a Spiders 19 team with Fu-shan. 

https://youtu.be/cyAvBWTAMUE

He is paired with a Psylar in stun set to control the spiderlings. 
Armiger and CH provide the TM control on the main spider and Max HP nukes.
Apothecary supports the team with Increase Speed, TM, and is the off-affinity tank.

Notice how Apothecary barely gets attacked due to the CC control of Fu-shan and Psylar. This team was not tuned properly, ideally you want Fu-shan to be faster than Armiger and CH so he places his Decrease Def before they nuke the main spider. The run will be faster if tuned better but it can get the job done for you if you're stuck at this stage.
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
Faction Wars

Fu-shan is a great FW champion. He brings the DPS, AOE Stun to CC the waves, Speed aura, and Decrease Defense, especially if you don’t have the stronger AOE Decrease Defense champion in Dracomorph or Roxam. 

Everyone should be able to get Rhazin but he only does it on a single target. The video belows showcases an easy Lizardmen FW 21 team with the Skull lord and Skullsworn combo. Broadmaw provides buffs and backup revives, Rhazin and Fu-shan as the main DPS.

https://youtu.be/uO7EzxFbYAU

data.desc:
In Mid Game setting Miscreated Monster (MM) can be an extremely valuable asset for completing any dungeon and campaign content. It is the stage of the game when you don't quite have the equipment to reach the simultaneous requirements of high Crit rate, Crit damage, HP, Speed and Accuracy at the same time.

In this guide the focus will be on the control side of MM to ensure he can apply the Decrease DEF, AOE Stuns and Fear debuffs. The masteries will follow the standard Offence route to deal damage. However, it will culminate in T6 Eagle Eye mastery that increases the Accuracy.

This Miscreated Monster specialises in control and can be used in any dungeons. This Guide will feature the champion in just one instance: farming 12-6 Nightmare Campaign with food to showcase the survivability. There are dungeon showcases including Spider in the guides on the next pages.
data.label: Masteries

data.desc:
MM is an HP-based character and his damage increases as you focus on it. Gearing him in Immortal sets is a strong option as it combines high survivability and damage in one package.

It is crucial to have over 200+ accuracy as much speed as you can get and over 70k hp to emulate this build if you cannot build enough Crit Rate and Crit Damage. This MM has less than 200 speed, however the masteries allow him to overcome this threshold as he kills the mobs and the food champions die.

Chest: HP %

Ring: HP
Amulet: Crit Damage

data.desc:
In the early game setting your main goal is to 6 star your starter and to start farming 12-3 brutal campaign. That part of campaign is where Diabolist lives and will eventually join your roster if you farm it.

Her main use is the Turn Meter Speed boost if you don't have better alternative champions and she requires low investment to help you in Arena to get from Bronze to Silver. As shown in the third slide and the Arena early guide you do not need to level her and do not need to have any masteries for her to work properly. In the featured video she doesn't have any masteries at all.

You can opt to ascend Diabolist to 3 stars and get her accuracy to allow her to decrease the Turn meter of enemies. However, that would require additional accuracy and maitaining both that and the high speed can be difficult for early game. Taking the first two Support tree Masteries can help with this, but it's not required
data.label: Masteries

data.desc:
To fulfil her speed boosting role the best, Diabolist quite simply needs to be the fastest on your team and has to be faster than your opponents. To achieve this - anything goes. This means that when you have equipment that may have bad main stats (e.g. gloves with flat hp) but good substat procs in speed you keep those items around and put them on your main speed booster.

This is especially true for 5 star gear and above as their speed substats become a significant source of additional speed. Speed mainstat boots are non-negotiable (5 star wanted for early game) and speed substats on all other pieces. You can farm that gear in brutal campaign.

The Speed set with 12% bonus is best in slot, but in this example random pieces with high speed rolls were used because the speed sets did not have enough speed substats. 

Accuracy is secondary, don't sacrifice Speed to get it. Perception sets can be helpful too, but it's best to use them on your Decrease DEF champion, in this Arena composition - Warmaiden. Accuracy is way more important for her role.

Rule of a thumb: 

If a Speed set (2 pieces) has no speed substats, 2 Random set pieces that add up to 13 speed substats or more are better than the pure Speed set. 

That can change for other champs with higher/lower basespeed.
data.label: Gear and stats

data.desc:
Note that you need to manual Diabolist in Arena as she will not use her A3 on auto. 

Going first in Bronze Arena nearly always means you win if you follow the basic sequence of

1. Be faster than your opponent
2. Don't let them cut into your turn sequence
3. Place AOE DEF Down
4. Nuke them

Focus on getting your Diabolist as much speed as possible and tuning your other champions according to the early game Arena guide to achieve similar results to the featured video

https://youtu.be/JecPqfhxEUs
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
Turvold is a Void affinity Barbarian Legendary champion that has one of the highest single target damage output in the game. This makes him a top tier damage dealer for Clan Boss if the conditions are met. 

His A3, Juggernaut, is capable of scaling with the number of buffs he has. If you like seeing Big Damage numbers, Turvold is the champion for you! Build a team around him and you’ll see those Big Numbers everyday in your CB battles.

People often avoid using Turvold in Clan Boss because he is quite difficult to speedtune in a team. He places increase speed on himself and gains extra turns which cycles the important buffs on him like counterattack, increase defense, or unkillable on him too quickly leaving him exposed. However, with the discovery of the Clan Boss turn meter mechanics, proper speedtunes and using the CB calculators it is possible to utilize Turvold in a tuned team. This guide will showcase Turvold in an Unkillable and standard Non-Unkillable Counterattack teams.

Booking Turvold is necessary as he benefits from a lower cooldown on both of his skill. Additionally, Turvold is all about doing dps, so getting the damage increase from the books matters as well.

Masteries on Turvold will be the standard CB ones. In the Offense tree, take Crit Rate, Crit Damage and all the CB damage increasing masteries on the left down to Warmaster. Life drinker is an important mastery to take for lifesteal when under 50% Health. Turvold does big hits, so even the 5% lifesteal heals a lot. This will enable to counterattack mastery on the Defense Tree which we will discuss now. In the Defense Tree, take the Damage mitigation mastery in Tough Skin, Blastproof, Delayed Death, into Retribution and Deterrence.

Those Masteries can be used for both Unkillable and Non-unkillable teams.
data.label: Masteries

data.desc:
Gearing Turvold is quite unique and will depend on which type of CB team you use him in. 

This first build will be used for a double Maneater unkillable team that uses Turvold as one of the DPS champions. The most important stat for any unkillable team is the speed. In this team, Turvold needs to be between 152–158 speed. Turvold also grants himself a 30% Crit Rate Buff, so you only need to build him with 70% Crit Rate. 

Once you have the required Speed and Crit Rate, you can focus entirely on Attack and Crit Damage. 5k+ Attack and 250%+ Crit Damage is ideal for the Big Damage numbers in Late Game+. If you need him to apply Weaken, an accuracy of 240+ is recommended for Ultra-Nightmare Clan Boss. You can ignore accuracy if it’s not needed. 

The best set for Turvold in an Unkillable team is Fury + Cruel but any combination of damage dealing sets like Cruel, Offense and Crit Damage are also an option. Due to the incredibly low speed needed for Turvold in this particular composition, you can quite easily gear Turvold without Speed boots and use all ATK % main stat items.

Glove: Crit Damage 
Chest: ATK %
Boots: ATK %
Ring: Attack
Amulet: Crit Damage 
Banner: Attack
data.label: Gear and stats

data.desc:
UK Clan Boss

This is an Unkillable UNM team that features Turvold as one of the DPS champions that is also built specifically to take advantage of Fu-shan’s Speed Aura. So, the speed on all the champions is lower than what they need to be without Fu-shan’s Aura but will hit the required speed in battle with the speed aura.

The speed settings used for this team are:

194 ME (218 after speed aura)
191 ME (214 after speed aura)
149 Kreela (172 after speed aura)
150 Fu-shan (175 after speed aura)
132 Turvold (154 after speed aura)

This is a team combination that takes advantage of Fu-shan and Kreela that provide Speed Aura and increase Crit Rate buff for the team. This allows everyone in this team to be built much better with the reduced stat requirement (Less speed and only 70% crit rate). This team has Decrease Defense from Fu-shan, Weaken from Turvold, Increase Attack, Crit Rate, and ally attack from Kreela to take advantage of everyone’s hard hitting A1, especially Fu-shan’s and Turvold’s. Two Maneaters provide permanent Block Debuffs and Unkillable for the team to function.

This team works on UNM, NM, and on all affinities. There is a manual setup before you can hit auto. The videos below shows the manual setup for UNM and NM.

This video showcases this team in action and easily hitting 1 Key in Ultra Nightmare CB

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GIeUoxfYB9o

This video showcase this team in NM with a slightly different set up.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GIeUoxfYB9o&t=6m20s

You can find more information about the Turvold unkillable team and their manual setup here 

https://www.deadwoodjedi.com/speed-tunes-4/Turvold-Double-Maneater-Unkillable

The next page will cover Turvold in a Counterattack CB team
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
Turvold is a Void affinity Barbarian Legendary champion that has one of the highest single target damage output in the game. This makes him a top tier damage dealer for Clan Boss if the conditions are met. This guide will focus on him in a Counterattack team setting.

His A3, Juggernaut, is capable of scaling with the number of buffs he has. If you like seeing Big Damage numbers, Turvold is the champion for you! Build a team around him and you’ll see those Big Numbers everyday in your CB battles.

People often avoid using Turvold in Clan Boss because he is quite difficult to speedtune in a team. He places increase speed on himself and gains extra turns which cycles the important buffs on him like counterattack, increase defense, or unkillable on him too quickly leaving him exposed. However, with the discovery of the Clan Boss turn meter mechanics, proper speedtunes and using the CB calculators it is possible to utilize Turvold in a tuned team. This guide will showcase Turvold in an Unkillable and standard Non-Unkillable Counterattack teams.

Booking Turvold is necessary as he benefits from a lower cooldown on both of his skill. Additionally, Turvold is all about doing dps, so getting the damage increase from the books matters as well.

Masteries on Turvold will be the standard CB ones. In the Offense tree, take Crit Rate, Crit Damage and all the CB damage increasing masteries on the left down to Warmaster. Life drinker is an important mastery to take for lifesteal when under 50% Health. Turvold does big hits, so even the 5% lifesteal heals a lot. This will enable to counterattack mastery on the Defense Tree which we will discuss now. In the Defense Tree, take the Damage mitigation mastery in Tough Skin, Blastproof, Delayed Death, into Retribution and Deterrence.

Those Masteries can be used for both Unkillable and Non-unkillable teams.
data.label: Masteries

data.desc:
In a standard Non-Unkillable CA team gearing Turvold will be different. In this specific team Turvold needs to be between 106–110 speed. Yes, you have read that right, he needs to be that slow. The next slide showcasing the team will explain the reason for this.

Turvold gives himself a 30% Crit Rate Buff, so you only need to build him with 70% Crit Rate. Since this is a non-unkillable team, Defense must also be considered when building Turvold. You want to build him with around 2.5k-3k Defense, with as much Attack and Crit Damage as possible, at least 4.5k+ Attack and 200%+ Crit Damage to deal significant dps. If you need him to apply Weaken, an accuracy of 220-250 is recommended. You can ignore accuracy if it is not needed. 

Lifesteal set is a must for a non-unkillable team (unless you have a Leech debuff) combined with any 2-piece set that gives you the stats you need such as Cruel, Offense, Crit Damage etc. Alternatively you can use items with good substat procs.

Due to the incredibly low speed needed for Turvold in this comp, you can quite easily gear Turvold without Speed boots and with all ATK/Def% main stat items with minimal speed substats.

You can use any combination of ATK/DEF% pieces and accessories to give you the recommended stats above.

Glove: Crit Damage 
Chest: ATK/DEF %
Boots: ATK/DEF %
Ring: Attack/Def
Amulet: Crit Damage 
Banner: Attack/Def
data.label: Gear and stats

data.desc:
CA Clan Boss

This is a specific team built to utilize Turvold in a speedtuned UNM CA team. The champions used in this team and their speed settings are as follows:

252 Sepulcher Sentinel (Provides Inc Def, Block Stun, Dec Atk)
226 Kreela (Provides Inc Crit Rate, Inc Atk, Ally Attack)
191 Skullcrusher (Provides CA, Ally protection)
175 Rhazin (Provides Def Def, Weaken, DPS)
106 Turvold (Provides Pure DPS)

This is a team combination specifically created to make Turvold shine. Sepulcher is running at a 4:3 to block the stun every time. Kreela is also running 4:3 to permanently give the team Increase Crit Rate Buff and perform ally attack when Dec Def/Weaken are placed to maximize damage. Rhazin provides the Dec Def/Weaken and secondary DPS. Skullcrusher with the team Counterattack and Ally Protection buff. 

With Turvold at 106 speed, he is running at 2:3, meaning he takes 2 turns for every 3 CB turns. In this team, he only takes a turn before AOE1 and after AOE2. He does not take a turn between AOE1 and AOE2. This means that he will have all the defensive buffs (Increase Def, Block Debuff, CA, Ally Protect) permanently allowing him to survive with only 2.5k-3k Def. His Extra turn skill is timed to be used before any buffs are placed so he doesn’t lose any buffs and his A3 Juggernaut is also timed to be used when he has the greatest number of buffs(7) on him for maximum damage.

This team unfortunately only works on UNM and as with any CA team, works on all affinities except Spirit due to the slow debuff.

The video below showcases the run as well as the manual set up for this team comfortably 2-keying UNM CB. You can see that Turvold is the highest damage dealer in this team even though he is only running 2:3.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3ybHL3-Smzc
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
In the early game setting your main goal is to 6 star your starter and to start farming 12-3 brutal campaign. Spirithost is a farmable champion that you can get from campaign.

She has a decent kit that includes a speed aura for Arena (useful until you get the guaranteed High Khatun or a better champion), ATK Up buff, Debuff Removal and Block Debuffs.

Investing in her heavily is not required at all in the early game, she can do her work just as well at 3 stars if she has the correct setup. In Arena we need her aura and lead and enough speed to go before the Nuking champion (and sometimes debuffer) to buff Attack. Note that this buff is not as mandatory as DEF Down debuff and Spirithost is usually the first one to be replaces in Arena teams.

Spirithost requires 3 star ascension to place a 50% increase ATK buff instead of 25%. 

As such no masteries were selected for her to keep the investment minimal.
data.label: Masteries

data.desc:
For arena, she doesn't need much except being faster than your debuffer (in this case Warmaiden, even if she doesn't deal that much damage) and your Nuker (Starter in early game). 

Any sets and any main stats of the artifacts can be used and you need to calibrate her speed based on your main Turn Meter Booster and the rest of the champions.

If you want to use her in dungeons, she also needs HP%/DEF% gloves and chest to survive. Speed boots are mandatory.
data.label: Gear and stats

data.desc:
Going first in Bronze Arena nearly always means you win if you follow the basic sequence of

1. Be faster than your opponent
2. Don't let them cut into your turn sequence
3. Place AOE DEF Down
4. Nuke them

Focus on getting your Spirithost to the right speed tune compared to your other champions according to the early game Arena guide to achieve similar results to the featured video

https://youtu.be/JecPqfhxEUs
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
In the early game setting your main goal is to 6 star your starter and to start farming 12-3 brutal campaign. Warmaiden is a farmable champion that you can get from campaign and she's arguably the one who sees the most late game usage out of all champins obtainable in campaign.

Warmaiden and other AOE DEF Down champions play an extremely important role in Arena. DEF Down increases the damage dealt by the nuker tremendously and defines the metagame all the way up to and including some of the Platinum tier. 

She is worth booking. You can do it using duplicates from the campaign or Rare books to book her A3 for 100% chance.

To place the debuffs she requires three things. 

1) She needs to be fast enough to place the debuff on the opponents
2) She needs to have enough Accuracy 
3) You need to be mindful of negative Affinity - Spirit champions

Thankfully, there are not that many meta Spirit Affinity champions in Bronze and Silver. You want to get the first two Accuracy masteries for Warmaiden because those give a huge boost especially early on.
data.label: Masteries

data.desc:
The best set for Warmaiden to fulfill her role are the Perception sets crafted in the Forge as they provide two most important stats for her: Accuracy and Speed. 

In this build 217 accuracy was overkill for bronze arena. 3x Accuracy sets or perception set are usually enough for this stage of the game (120 accuracy without any substats). 

Make sure to prioritise speed and accuracy substats for her on 4 star gear and higher apart from just the set bonuses.

Glove: Any
Chest: Accuracy
Boots: Speed
Ring: Any

If you want to use Warmaiden in dungeons, she should also have some HP and DEF (HP%/DEF% Gloves and Chest). Accuracy chest was used here because she is 3 star with minimal investment. She is very squishy, and not used outside of Arena in this case.
data.label: Gear and stats

data.desc:
Going first in Bronze Arena nearly always means you win if you follow the basic sequence of

1. Be faster than your opponent
2. Don't let them cut into your turn sequence
3. Place AOE DEF Down
4. Nuke them

Warmaiden fits her role in this team easily as long as she has enough speed and Accuracy. you can see the video below and check the early Arena guide that is the counterpart

https://youtu.be/JecPqfhxEUs

On the next page you can see how Warmaiden is used in the Mid Game setting
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
Norog is a DEF based Magic Affinity Legendary Champion from the Skinwalkers Faction that has a relatively simple yet effective skill kit. 

His A1 and A2 have good multipliers so he can hit hard, but the debuffs these two abilities apply are for the most part irrelevant. His passive ability Thick Skin is his most important ability. He is immune to all hard CC (Stun, Freeze, and Sleep) and provides a team wide damage reduction. 

To put his damage reduction into perspective Stalwart set is an amazing set that provides 30% damage reduction from AOE attacks but is a 4-piece set. Norog’s passive provides half of this effect (15%) at worst case for ANY attacks, not just AOE. Best case scenario it’s slightly less damage reduction for ANY attacks for the team (25%). Since most of his utility is in his passive, he does not require any books at all to be effective making him cheap to build on a budget.

He is a great champion for Ice Golem, a Solid CB Champion if you’re still lacking the end-game CB champions, and is one of the best for Skinwalkers Faction Wars. With the release of the two new Doom Tower Bosses, Eternal Dragon and Celestial Griffin his passive fits perfectly as a great option for those bosses.

Masteries on this Norog build are fairly simple. Since his debuffs are irrelevant, we will take the Offense and Defense Tree. In the Offense Tree, the standard Clan Boss damage dealing masteries are chosen. Crit Rate, Crit Damage and all the CB damage increasing masteries on the left down to Warmaster. In the Defense Tree, take the Damage mitigation mastery in Tough Skin, Blastproof, Delayed Death into Counterattack masteries, Retribution and Deterrence.
data.label: Masteries

data.desc:
Gearing Norog is also quite simple. You want to prioritize building him with Defense, Crit Rate, Crit Damage, and Speed. Ideally 4k+ Defense, 100% Crit Rate, 200%+ Crit Damage, and enough speed to fit your CB speed tune team if you use him there. If you’re not using him in CB, then as much speed as possible, around 200+.

For Clan Boss, Lifesteal set is a must, unless you have Leech in your team. You can then use any 2-piece set to maximize your stats. For any other non-CB content, you can gear him with any set in the game since all you need on him are pure damaging stats. He is a perfect champion to fit your broken gear pieces that have amazing substats. 

Glove: Crit Rate / Crit Damage
Chest: Def %
Boots: Def % / Speed
Ring: Def
Amulet: Crit Damage
Banner: Def

The Norog build shown here is used in a speed tuned Clan Boss team, hence the 172 speed in Lifesteal. This exact build can be used in any other content but if you are not using him in CB, having more speed, 200+ is recommended, and he will perform much better. An example of a 200+ Speed Norog with broken pieces: https://imgur.com/9xu71kG
data.label: Gear and stats

data.desc:
Norog’s utility in Clan Boss is his passive damage reduction for the team and being immune to stun. Norog can be built as the stun target. On Void, put him in the lead position so the CB will target him. Affinities will be more complex;

1)        Force – The easiest to set up since Norog is weak affinity. You can position Norog anywhere, but he must go before any other Magic champion you have in your team.  eg. if you have a FB, Norog should be positioned before her so the CB will target Norog first (Norog at a slot 2, FB at slot 4). This means that you do not have to put Norog in the lead. If you have champions of other affinities with an aura, you can use them as lead. 

This is the how positioning is prioritized:

4th 2nd
               1st (Lead)
5th 3rd

2)        Magic – You must not have any Spirit champion in your team as the Magic CB will always target it. Without a Spirit champion, you can position Norog after your Force champions since CB will not target Force champions. If you have a Force champion like Sepulcher Sentinel, you can use her as lead and put Norog in the other slots (You must still follow the same concept as Force above if you have other Magic champions in your team).  

3)        Spirit – Norog cannot be the stun target for Spirit because he is a positive affinity there and a standard CA team usually don’t work in Spirit anyway due to the slow debuff.

This is an example of a Late game CB team built to use Norog as the stun target.
1)        Norog (172)
2)        Skullcrusher (171)
3)        Rhazin (176)
4)        Godseeker Aniri (172)
5)        Sepulcher (227)

This team works on UNM and NM, all affinity except Spirit. This video shows this team running on UNM and NM. The UNM run unfortunately ended early due to missing ATK down but was still able to 3 key and the NM run comfortably 1 key. You can reach 2 key territory with Norog if that is your goal.

https://youtu.be/NcNeUl764c4

The following pages will showcase Norog in dungeons and Doom Tower
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
Ice Golem 20

Norog is a great champion for Ice Golem as he provides protection from the hard hitting AOE damage through his passive. 

He also deals decent amount of damage to help take down the Ice Golem and cannot be frozen. 

Stag Knight has AOE Def Down and ATK Down for further damage reduction and speeding up the runs. 
Dark Elhain is a damage dealer that can utilize her passive to convert the Freeze debuff into damage on the boss stage.
Gorgorab provides Increase Attack, TM boosting, healing and resurrection.
Scyl provides additional support through passive healing, CC, and backup resurrection if things go South. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NcNeUl764c4&t=9m39s
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
Faction Wars

The Skinwalker faction has very limited options and most of them are not amazing. Norog is definitely one of the best options for this faction in Faction Wars. 

Since this faction does not currently have any revivers, it is very important to survive and not to let your champions kick the bucket to get the 3* completion. Norog’s passive damage reduction helps with that. The FW21 boss here is the one that swaps buffs, leaving your team without any buffs, hence triggering the bigger (25%) damage reduction from Norog’s passive. He is also a solid damage dealer, which is needed since this boss swaps health and you need to take down the bosses before he can swap health again.

This video shows a Skinwalker 21 stage done on auto, but if you need to complete this stage for the first time, you should consider running this stage on manual and time placing Fayne’s debuffs after the boss uses the transfers Debuffs skill. Having all the Debuffs from Fayne transferred back to your team may cause your team to take too much damage and wipe before clearing.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wC-uJOvT8E4&t=13m42s
data.label: Notes:

data.desc: Reserved. The next page will deal with Norog Doom Tower bosses showcases
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
Celestial Griffin

Norog’s passive is actually incredibly well suited for the Griffin. His passive reduces the damage your team takes by 25% without buffs and 15% with buffs. The Griffin will always strip your buffs and the so the 25% damage reduction is almost always in effect. At worst case where you have buffs up, the 15% damage reduction is still there, so a win-win situation. Building him with 200+ speed here will be much better here rather than the 170+ speed for CB.

The team used for Hard Stage 90 Celestial Griffin is as follows:

1)        Scyl of the Drakes
2)        Rotos
3)        Norog
4)        Drexthar
5)        Doompriest

Scyl provides support to the team with her constant heals, increase speed, and emergency revives. 
Norog provide passive team damage reduction and is a secondary DPS for the Boss. 
His passive is even more effective here at providing the full 25% damage reduction because the Griffin constantly strips buffs. 
Rotos and Drexthar provide DPS. 
Doompriest provides additional support with her heals and cleanse the debuffs places or transferred to your team each turn. 

The video below shows this team on full auto farm with 100% Win rate. As you can see, the team can sustain and doesn’t even come close to dying. The team does enough DPS to take down the Griffin even before it reaches the max Sky Bond stacks. 

https://youtu.be/68E3FSYfByE
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
Eternal Dragon

Norog’s passive is also incredibly well suited for the Eternal Dragon. His passive reduces the damage your team takes by 25% without buffs and 15% with buffs. The Dragon locks out your skills so you can’t put up buffs, so the 25% damage reduction is almost always in effect. At worst case where you have buffs up, the 15% damage reduction is still there, so a win-win situation 

The team used for Hard Stage 120 Eternal Dragon is as follows:

1)        Scyl of the Drakes
2)        Vrask
3)        Norog
4)        Drexthar
5)        Jareg

Scyl provides support to the team with her constant heals, increase speed, AOE stuns, and emergency revives. Scyl is built with a high enough resistance to resist all the Dragon’s Skill Cooldown affecting abilities so, she can still CC the minions and revive dead allies. 

Norog provides passive team damage reduction from the Dragon’s Hard hitting AOE and is a secondary DPS. 

Drexthar is the main damage dealer through his AOE HP Burns 

Jareg places Decrease Attack on the boss to reduce incoming damage and places a Continuous Heal buff on your team after taking the Dragon’s hard hitting AOE. 

Vrask provides additional team healing since the heal from Scyl and Jareg is not enough to sustain the team. 

The video below shows this team on full auto. 

https://youtu.be/68E3FSYfByE
data.label: Notes:

data.desc: Reserved.
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
Duchess Lilitu is one of the most versatile champions in Raid and can be used in any area. She continues to be relevant in all content, although there are variations in builds. This guide will cover her in Platinum Arena, all dungeons, Faction Wars, Doom Tower and Clan Boss.

Booking her A2 and A3 for decreased cooldowns to take advantage of the Buffs she provides and the mass revive is needed. Her A1 shield does not provide much benefit when booked so if you were able to get the upgrades for her other skills don't spend extra books.

Her A2 provides three important buffs: Block Debuffs that helps against a variety or threats. ATK Up that can help your damage dealers and Perfect Veil that hides the rest of the team and reduces incoming AOE damage by 15% synergizing well with Duchess passive that further reduces AOE damage by 25% (15% vs bosses).

In terms of masteries Lilitu is relatively easy to build. She needs as much survivability as possible in a standard build. Her T6 mastery choice will depend on how you're planning to use her.

If you are using her for Clan Boss you will want to pick Warmaster as the T6 mastery. This will be the discussed in the respective CB build further down the line.

If you are using Lilitu to break into top Platinum you might want to use a specialised build with Timely Intervention and a Swift Parry set ignoring stacking the Resistance and opting for more speed, HP/DEF. This is a new variation and not covered here.

Outside of those cases the golden standard for Lilitu for a long time has been to stack her with 600+ Resistance for Platinum Arena and use her everywhere. This will be the main showcase build that still works for a majority of players.

In this build Unshakable is selected as the T6 mastery for +50 Resistance. Masteries that increase the chances to survive are all selected in the Support and the Defence trees. This allows Lilitu to become one of the tankiest champions for all content and provides a lifeline to your team even if they are fully wiped.
data.label: Masteries

data.desc:
Gearing for Lilitu in this build is quite straightforward. You prefer 600+ Resistance for Platinum Arena or at least 350+ for Hard Doom Tower. 240+ Speed is wanted for Lilitu so that she is sufficiently fast to cycle through her skills. Everything else is spent on maximising her HP and DEF for survivability.

She can use any sets for gearing. Speed sets and Resistance sets are good baselines. However, the substats and glyphs play an important role in Late Game+. Great Hall upgrades can also help reach the required parameters.

It should also be noted that the Clan vs Clan Reflex jewellery is amazing on Lilitu and if you have it and use her in Arena this should be a priority for her.

Glove: HP%/DEF%
Chest: Resistance
Boots: Speed
Ring: HP/DEF
Amulet: HP/DEF 
Banner: Resistance
data.label: Gear and stats

data.desc:
There are more than 400 champions in Raid. But there are only a select few that consistently show up in Platinum Arena and Lilitu is one of them. If you are using the standard universal build with Resistance you can use her both in Attack and Defence.

Lilitu is not meant to be used in a Speed boost team that is a staple for Gold IV and below. She is the grindy champion that makes your team survive thanks to her kit. Her Block Debuffs allows the team to avoid Tormin freeze. Her Perfect Veil and passive reduce the incoming AOE damage and make the enemies focus her. 

Reviving with 70% health makes it possible to prolong your fights. In the video below you can see how this can be applied in practice.

https://youtu.be/z7F-CMpBY18?t=205

The opposing team goes first and the two Trundas take down Mortu. Repeatedly reviving him so he can apply Peril to block revive allows the team to clinch the victory thanks to Duchess. You can find the full video below

https://youtu.be/z7F-CMpBY18

This pattern is repeated throughout the fights and Lilitu is quite flexible in terms of champions she can work with. She can synergise extremely well with Candraphone, Mortu, Rotos and many other heavy damage dealers. Candraphone specifically can be a monster with her and the permanent Perfect Veil can help him hit extremely hard as shown in the video below.

https://youtu.be/6jUZbrdFBbs

We will be covering Lilitu in the dungeons on the next page
data.label: Notes:

title: Duchess Lilitu Late Game+ Dungeon Runs

data.desc:
Duchess Lilitu can work in any dungeon no matter the level or affinity. For Dragon 20 she is negative affinity, but this doesn't stop her at all. The combination of high resistance, HP, DEF and speed means you will be able to complete this dungeon in variety of ways with Lilitu as the main enabling champion.

For Late Game+ Setting Duchess can also be helpful. She is one of the select group of champions that has 3 buffs on her A2 skill. This synergies well with Seer and allows speed runs in dungeons.

Note that there is a shield set on Renegade to add additional buffs that Seer can use for Karma burn. Additionally, removing the buffs inluding Perfect Veil makes your champions more vulnerable to AOE Damage. However, for speed runs you usually one-shot waves anyway and have a way do deal with the bosses before it starts to matter.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fFcLWf-FuWM

In this case Dracomorph serves as the DEF Down/Weaken champion
Lilitu provides the buffs
Seer is the main damage dealer for waves
Zavia is the poisoner for the boss
Renegade decreases the skill cooldowns

This team could be refined further for faster runs.
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
Fire Knight 20 is a good affinity for Duchess Lilitu. She can be a comfortable pick for this dungeon.

Lilitu can carry your team through the waves and revive if needed. On the boss she provides the damage reduction that can help your team survive longer. The team composition is standard for speed runs.

Lilitu as the enabler and reviver
Dracomorph as the DEF Down/Weaken (note that it's not affected by affinity)
Seer as the wave clearer
Two Coldhearts for MAX HP damage nukes and full TM Depletion on the boss. Heal reduction debuff is also relevant but by this stage of the game it's redundant. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ln8YrUOIUu4
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
Spider 20 is one of the most popular dungeons for both the jewellery and silver farming. While Lilitu is not the most useful champion for speed runs there, she can provide this buff as part of her kit and protect the squishy champions from their demise thanks to the perfect Veil.

In this composition

Spider champion places DEF Down/Weaken and provides a speed Aura (note that it's not affected by affinity)
Scyl provides AOE Stuns, healing and Decrease Speed on Skavag
Coldheart is a MAX HP Nuke champion and full TM depletion
Septimus is a MAX HP Nuker
Lilitu provide the ATK Up buff and protects the rest of the champions

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OqvDpI3tktY

Lilitu also has a specific synergy with Ultimate Galek who can provide AOE HP Burn conditional if he has the ATK UP buff. ATK Up is a part of her kit and can work well as an enabler for him

https://youtu.be/1eDF9qF7p58
data.label: Notes:

title: Duchess Lilitu Late Game+ Dungeon Runs 2

data.desc:
The last regular dungeon that is covered in this guide is Ice Golem 20. The speed runs with Seer are viable in this case and the example team makeup is as follows:

Dracomorph as the DEF Down/Weaken champion 
Lilitu as the enabler for Seer, block debuffs provider and dmg reduction from AOE attacks
Archmage Helmut as the provider of additional buffs in particular speed buff and Crit Damage buff for Septimus
Seer as the wave nuker. Note how she dies during on the second wave due to reflect.
Septimus as a single target MAX HP Nuker

Note that a shield set to add additional buffs so that Seer can use the buff for Karma burn is a good idea. However, removing the buffs inluding Perfect Veil makes your champions more vulnerable to AOE Damage on the boss stage. For speed runs you usually one-shot waves and have a way do deal with the bosses before it starts to matter, but use this with caution in this dungeon.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LjUXOdQpbX8
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
Lilitu is a faction defining champion if you pull her. Nearly any team can work with her, even some funky compositions that rely on Souldrinker bombs to be placed and activated on his death only to be revived by Duchess.

In a standard setting the only wave that can realistically be a problem with Lilitu with this build is the second wave of crypt 21 with Valkyries that get a turn meter boost from her buffs. The way to deal with it during runs are 

1) Turn meter reduction with champions like Alure, Diabolist, Countess Lyx
2) Control with champions like Kymar 
3) AOE Provoke strategies with Umbral Enchantress and Dexthar.

Duchess can supplement any combination of those strategies and facilitate runs on auto.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AvJdzQv3Jz4
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
We will continue with the Duchess Lilitu showcase as we cover the hard Doom Tower (DT). Two hard DT rotations have shown that she is as viable as ever in both of them. 

Tormins on wave 112 can prove to be a problem for many a team, but not for those with Duchess Lilitu. The Block Debuffs skill from her lasts two turns and doesn't freeze on application making her one of the best in slot champions for this role.

The featured team relies on Lilitu for Block Debuffs
Venus provides the DEF Down/Weaken
Nethril and Lyssandra provide TM control
Big'Un is the damage dealer and CC

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uoC8kGGsryI

On the next slide we will go over the hardest wave of the first Doom Tower rotation and the bosses.
data.label: Notes:

title: Duchess Lilitu Late Game+ Dungeon Runs 3

data.desc:
The combination of Siphi and Rotos is one of the strongest threats in Doom Tower, especially on the second wave of floor 114. If you are not one-shotting with Seer (except for Rotos) there are not that many options to pass it. The main reasons are

1) Siphi's passive removes all debuffs from Rotos when he takes a turn
2) Rotos becomes stronger making it only a question of time until he leeches enough HP and starts wiping out your team completely. And on second wave there are two Rotos waiting for you.

The featured team relies on Turn Meter control to prevent the problematic champions from taking a turn. Duchess saves and protects the team in case of mishaps.

The featured team relies on Lilitu for Block Debuffs
Venus provides the DEF Down/Weaken
Nethril and Lyssandra provide TM control
Big'Un is the damage dealer and CC

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mz5uDZUQDBY

Note how the run had required to restart to keep the optimal combination of champions and skills for the waves. The run is better done on manual to keep the skills cooldown in check and apply it intelligently
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
Magma Dragon is one of the easier Doom Tower bosses. Most teams that farm it rely on its weakness to the Provoke debuff. In the featured team

Lilitu provides Block Debuffs, revive and damage reduction passive
Warchief provides the constant single target Provoke on the boss
Rhazin is the DEF Down/Weaken applicator
Royal Guard helps with the wave clearing and some damage
Arbiter for Speed Buff and TM buff

With the nerf to MAX HP damage on bosses you can replace Royal Guard with any champion who can help clear the waves and deal damage to the boss including poisoners.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e6nKp1_nrWc
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
Nether Spider can be a problematic boss in hard Doom Tower, especially if he is Magic for Lilitu. However, Duchess can still be useful there.

While Block Debuffs doesn't help against poisons on the boss stage, the ability to revive the whole team with a huge health pool is invaluable and allows the team to grind down the waves and the boss on auto.

Lilitu - revive and AOE Damage reduction
Drexthar - the main damage dealer as both the Nether spider and spiderlings attack him and apply burn for the AOE effect
Rotos - damage dealer and helps clear the waves faster. Easiest to replace.
Doompriest - removal of debuffs and healing from passive
Scyl - Decrease Speed debuff and healing

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W-gfh7CwfCQ

In the next slide we continue to cover the Doom Tower bosses.
data.label: Notes:

title: Duchess Lilitu Late Game+ Dungeon Runs 4

data.desc:
Celestial Griffin can be a problematic boss to tackle. Thankfully, Duchess Lilitu has the kit to help with completion.

In this composition she reduces damage from AOE attacks and provides revive in case some of the champions die in the process. Griffin hits extremely hard at maximum stacks of his passive and champions below 50% health get extra hits on them. Reviving at 70% health on a low cooldown once again makes Lilitu a viable enabler on this boss.

Scyl is the secondary reviver in this fight as towards the end Lilitu alone may not be enough or the boss may take her out of comission. Her passive healing helps keep everyone topped up.

Rotos is the main damage dealer and stacks up good damage over time. His A2 and passive allow him to stay alive well throughout the fight.

Drexthar is the secondary damage dealer. He is able to permanently keep the boss under the HP burn debuff

Finally, Doompriest can remove the few debuffs the boss reflects on your team and the passive can heal the team back up.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4ucDjprH2wQ
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
Eternal Dragon can be a problematic boss in hard Doom Tower. As all the attacks on the stage are AOE, Duchess can be of help with reducing the incoming damage. Short Cooldowns on skills helps in this boss so the team composition has to take this into account.

Lilitu takes center stage once again with her kit and revive on a short cooldown
Nekhret provides increased survivability for the team
Tyrant ensures further AOE damage reduction with his passive and AOE HP Burn application
Bad el-Kazar main purpose is healing and debuff removal on short cooldown
Doompriest provides healing from the passive and debuff removal

https://youtu.be/IOkmjMtNbi8

The team relies on having short cooldowns of skills and to survive while the HP burn ticks take out the boss
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
Reserved.

For a one-key UNM composition with Lilitu see next page
data.label: Notes:

title: Duchess Lilitu Late Game+ Clan Boss Guide

data.desc:
Duchess Lilitu was the original member of one of the first team compositions to achieve one-key Ultra-Nightmare Clan Boss without Unkillable.

While there are now multitudes of other ways to get this White Whale composition working that don't require her to be present and it's recommended to use her in other areas where she shines the most (e.g. Platinum arena) we shall touch upon this piece of history in this guide.

You need to book Lilitu A2 for the Block Debuffs to be applied consistently during the CB stun phase.

The masteries are standard for most CB builds. As this build requires on the proper speed tuning no turn meter increasing masteries are allowed. Crit Rate, Crit Damage into Warmaster T6 were picked in the Offence tree. Damage reducing masteries were selected in the Defence tree as Lilitu is the designated Stun receiver from CB in this particular composition.
data.label: Masteries

data.desc:
The composition relies on Valkyrie Shields to protect the team most of the time. As such lifesteal is not required for this build. The prevailing theory at the time when the build was used suggested that the clan boss stun is based on enemy MAX HP. Hence most builds were focused on maximising DEF and minimising HP to survive for longer periods of time.

Exhaustive testing since then has found that enemy MAX HP from Clan Boss is capped, so in fact you can have as much HP as you want and it would benefit your team and Lilitu more as long as she continues to be the stun target.

Aiming for at least 4k+ DEF, sufficient speed and ideally 100% Crit Rate and Crit Damage would allow to maximise her utility on Clan Boss. However, the main draw of this composition is the 2:1 ratio that has to be maintained.

Glove: DEF% / HP%
Chest: HP% / DEF%
Boots: Speed
Ring: HP
Amulet: HP
Banner: HP/DEF
data.label: Gear and stats

data.desc:
The team composition relies on constant Speed buff along with Counterattack to achieve 2:1 on UNM CB. The Leech Debuff from Ma'Shalled allows additional survivability for the team. This holds true for all White Whale Compositions, you can read about it in more detail here: https://www.deadwoodjedi.com/speed-tunes-4/White-Whale---Ma%27Shalled

Note the speed required for each champion because it's one of the key requirements for this comp to work. While there are multiple possible compositions, the classic one is covered in the video below:

https://youtu.be/mrpk1zaDQI8

In this team Lilitu provides Block Debuffs during the stun and AOE Damage reduction with the passive and Perfect Veil. At the time the video was uploaded the Veil damage reduction was a part of Duchess passive

Ma'Shalled is the key champion in this composition providing Leech Debuff, Speed Buff and Crit Damage Buff for the team. He cannot be stunned in order for this to work.

Valkyrie provides AOE Counterattack buff and massive shields if she has the DEF Up buff on her when she casts them.

Altan is the one who provide the DEF Up for the team and ATK Down on the CB.

Finally, Dracomorph is one of the best CB Damage dealers as he has access to DEF Down, Weaken, Poisons and hard hitting A1 that is conditional on the number of debuffs.
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
Ignatius is currently the only legendary champion that has an AOE HP burn that can't be resisted. This makes him the best in slot character to deal with with Frost Spider in Doom Tower. 

Offense and defence trees were selected. The idea is to make your Ignatius as tanky as possible, with the ability to counter attack with the Retribution mastery. Like with most dungeon champions builds, Warmaster was selected T6 mastery due to the sheer size of Frost Spider HP pool, no other mastery comes even close in terms of damage potential as Warmaster. 

Warmaster and Retribution are key for sustain on the Ignatius, due to the fact that you will be running him in Life Steal gear. Accuracy is not needed so there is little value in the support tree in this specific scenario.
data.label: Masteries

data.desc:
Keep in mind that if you use Ignatius in a team with lots of healing, AOE damage reduction (e.g. Lilitu, Norog), Resistance Auras you can get away with less stats than in this build.

Life Steal set would work best for DT along with 2 broken set pieces that give the crucial sub stats, specifically crit rate, speed and resistance. If there are pieces from 2 set gear sets that can be used (speed, immortal, defence, etc.) go ahead and use it instead of broken sets. 

In order for your Ignatius to be successful you will need lots of resistance, preferably as close to 400 as possible or more if you can. 

When it comes to other stats, you want to have at least 4k DEF as well as ~40K HP, in the case of Ignatius, since he will be the only source of damage, in order to deal with the waves effectively you will need to run crit damage gloves on him as well as crit damage necklace.

His speed should be around 200, just like with any champion it is preferable to cap the crit rate or be as close to 100% as possible. 

Glove: Crit Damage % / Crit Rate %
Chest: Def% / Resistance
Boots: Speed
Ring: Def
Amulet: Def
Banner: Resistance
data.label: Gear and stats

data.desc:
It is important to have a support champion with revive that can guide Ignatius through the waves, especially wave 2 that has a very difficult group that it is almost impossible to solo through. 

The key on the support champion is to have more HP than Ignatius once they both make it to the Boss, support champion will just die and Ignatius will do the job.

The Frozen Spider boss and the spiderlings on hard DT have a huge health pool that allows AOE HP burn to deal damage fast and efficiently. As shown in the video below if you are lucky enough to have Ignatius you will be able to pass rooms with this boss easily. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_zFo9Nko9WY

This setup allows Ignatius to feel extremely comfortable in other content, such as Ice Golem 20, Nightmare Campaign Farming and solo Minotaur among others (featured on the next page)

However, building such a strong Ignatius comes with one drawback - in Spider 20 he hits too hard and spiderlings die before the full benefit of AOE HP burn is realised. If you plan on using him for Spider you will need less crit rate, dmg and defence.
data.label: Notes:

title: Yoshi the Drunkard Late Game+ Guide

data.desc:
Yoshi was the first Shadowkin champion to be offered for fusion. He has an interesting skill kit with A3 being the most highly prized one as it offers access to AOE Increase Accuracy and ATK UP buffs.

As such, if this is the only function you are using him for you do not need to book his other skills. If you are aiming to take the full advantage of his skillset you may want to book his other skills for extra chance to apply Crow Control (CC) skills like the stun and Decrease Accuracy.

In the Late Game+ Setting the areas that may require increased Accuracy buffs are Platinum Arena and Doom Tower where enemies may have huge resistance. This naturally impacts the choice of masteries

Both Rapid Response and Arcane Celerity are strong and provide an increase of his Turn Meter (TM) since he provides both buffs and debuffs. As an arena CC champ, you would like to use Evil Eye to decrease the TM of the enemies and finally you would want to use Eagle Eye as the T6 mastery to increase his accuracy even further to face resist teams in the arena. 

You can take the defense tree for more survivability as his kit isn't really meant for damage. Like most arena champions you should choose retribution to get a chance to remove debuffs if the enemy goes first. You can finish with both counterattack masteries as his a1 can apply stun as this can benefit you. This set of masteries works perfectly for CC in PVE content like Doom Tower.
data.label: Masteries

data.desc:
The key to Yoshi's kit for arena is Accuracy and Speed. In this sense, perception/accuracy sets are strong options for him. However, the best in slot set If you are aiming for platinum arena would be either Immunity gear or Untouchable with Perception. This allows Yoshi to work him against Tormin and Hegemon teams.

For PVE content like dungeons 20 around 220 Accuracy is sufficient. In hard Doom Tower 360 is preferred for the highest stages. The requirements fo Platinum Arena Accuracy for Yoshi are high and around 400-500 should be sufficient.

In terms of speed Yoshi needs to be tuned for Arena so his speed is sufficient to go after the main TM booster, e.g. Arbiter or Siphi without enemies cutting into the turn order. Using an arena calculator may be a good idea to make the correct calculations that depend on your team. For PVE 200+ speed is recommended.

Glove: DEF% / HP% / Crit Rate
Chest: Accuracy/ HP%
Boots: Speed
Ring: HP
Amulet: HP/DEF
Banner: Accuracy

For the chest, you have a choice you can either go accuracy chest if you want to use him in high arena (G4, plat) or you can go with HP% for Doom Tower (if you've reached the 400 acc for the hardest stages). You can either go crit rate or HP gloves depending on your need for survivability. With 270+ speed, he should be able to cut in even when the ennemy Arbiter places her buff, being able to apply True fear on the Enemy. If you run Yoshi with a reviver in Arena and DT you can use Crit Rate gloves for extra damage.
data.label: Gear and stats

data.desc:
The following three videos showcase Yoshi against high resistance teams in high gold and platinum arena. Yoshi shines the most when the enemy team has high resistance, around 700-800 in platinum. Teams like this are usually stall team that don't have high speed and instead try to waste as much time as possible for the attackers, especially at the Arena reset. They usually contain Hegemons that will always go first, champions with huge shields like Krisk, Tormins to freeze speed teams and other nasty traps.

The featured team is in Immunity sets because it prevents Tormin passive and Hegemon CC. Yoshi works even better with Lyssandra or Kymar since he also places the Increase Atk buff if you don't use Arbiter or Duchess.

Duchess is used here as a shield champion against nuke Hegemons but any champ with a high base HP can work with bulwark mastery. 
Yoshi provides the Accuracy buff
Madame Serris strips the buffs and takes advantage of the Yoshi utility. Note that Serris is guaranteed to use A3 on auto if your teams has the Block debuffs on them
Trunda is the nuker

https://youtu.be/iRWLmIz7vvY

If you want to go fo first you can also use Arbiter as lead and keep the rest of the team the same

https://youtu.be/e1QfEdiGatw

In theses videos  we can see that this team had no issue debuffing champions with high resist that were using Siphi and Warlord auras. Keep in mind that Valkyrie passive decreases the TM of champions that have Block buffs if she has a high enough Accuracy.

https://youtu.be/ty9y5Z-HhHI

Finally, Yoshi can also be used against Frost Spider that requires extremely high Accuracy to land the debuffs as seen in the video below

https://youtu.be/aRtS_O3DE-Y?t=614
data.label: Notes:

title: Scyl Late Game+ Dungeons Runs and Doom Tower

data.desc:
With the release of the new Doom Tower Bosses - Celestial Griffin and Eternal Dragon, Scyl of the Drakes is once again useful in new content. Her build can work better with slight adjustments to the original Late Game+ Build in terms of equipment.

Resistance is the top priority for the new build. At least 380 resistance is needed to reliably resist the highest stage of Hard Doom Tower (120). A high Speed, Defense and enough accuracy stats are still necessary to perform well. At least 200 speed, 4k Defense, and around 250+ Accuracy are recommended. She doesn't need as much accuracy because she's not applying her debuffs to the boss, but the minions. 

Once again, Relentless set works amazingly for Scyl and is highly recommended. She benefits  from being able to take multiple turns as she passively heals and provides Increase Speed buffs to your team as well as lowers her cooldown.

However, the stats are still important. Relentless set are hard to come by. Do not build her in Relentless set if you cannot achieve the required stats. She can work just as well with pure Speed, Perception, Resistance sets or even random items as long as you meet the required stats.

Glove: Def %
Chest: Resistance
Boots: Speed
Ring: Defense
Amulet: Defense
Banner: Resistance
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
The team used for Hard Stage 90 Celestial Griffin is as follows:

1)        Scyl of the Drakes
2)        Rotos
3)        Norog
4)        Drexthar
5)        Doompriest

Scyl provides support to the team with her passive heals, Increase Speed, and emergency revives. 
Norog provides team damage reduction and is a secondary DPS for the Boss. His passive is even more effective here at providing the full 25% damage reduction because the Griffin constantly strips buffs. 
Rotos and Drexthar provide DPS. 
Doompriest provides additional support with her heals and cleanses the debuffs transferred back to your team each turn. 

The video below shows this team on full auto farm with 100% Win rate. As you can see, the team can sustain and doesn’t come close to dying. The team does enough DPS to take Griffin down before it reaches the maximum Sky Bond stacks. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=68E3FSYfByE&t=8m34s
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
The team used for Hard Stage 120 Eternal Dragon is as follows:

1)        Scyl of the Drakes
2)        Vrask
3)        Norog
4)        Drexthar
5)        Jareg

Scyl provides support to the team with her constant heals, Increase speed, AOE stuns against the minions, and emergency revives. Scyl is built with a high enough resistance to resist all the Dragon’s Skill Cooldown affecting abilities so, she can still CC the minions and revive dead allies. 

Norog provides passive team damage reduction from the Dragon’s Hard hitting AOE and is a secondary DPS. 

Drexthar is the main damage dealer through his AOE HP Burn applied when the enemies attack. 

Jareg places Decrease Attack on the boss to reduce incoming damage and places a Continuous Heal buff on your team after taking the Dragon’s hard hitting AOE. 

Vrask provides additional team healing since the heal from Scyl and Jareg is not enough to sustain the team. 

The video below shows this team on full auto. Note the composition that utilises champions that have low skills cooldown for maximum efficiency and relies on healing and damage reduction while Drexthar burns your way to victory.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=68E3FSYfByE&t=13m52s
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
Doompriest is a Force Affinity Epic Champion from the Knight Revenants Faction with a simple yet effective skill kit. 

Her A1 and A2, are mostly irrelevant but her Passive ability is what makes this champion shine. Her passive heals and cleanses random debuffs on all allies every time she takes a turn. It turns out that cleansing a random debuffs from all allies every turn is an incredibly useful ability to have in a team as it helps negate the core mechanic of almost all the bosses in the game. 

This guide will feature Doompriest in different areas of the game. Her main role in the team is always to cleanse and heal your team, so anywhere a constant cleanse is required, she will be useful. This includes Ice Golem, Dragon, Faction wars, Clan Boss, and most of the Doom Tower Bosses.

Masteries are actually not important for Doompriest but can definitely improve her performance if you decide to invest in her. Masteries on Doompriest are straightforward. Take the Offense and Defense Tree. In the Offense Tree, the PVE damage dealing masteries are chosen. Crit Rate, Crit Damage and all the damage increasing masteries on the left down to Warmaster since she doesn’t really do much raw damage. 

In the Defense Tree, take the Damage mitigation mastery in Tough Skin, Blastproof, Delayed Death to improve survivability into Cycle of Revenge for TM increase to take as many turns as possible.  

Note that if you are using her for CB, avoid Cycle of Revenge and instead take the Counterattack masteries as the TM boost can break your speed tune. This is covered in the CB portion of the guide.
data.label: Masteries

data.desc:
Gearing Doompriest is also quite simple. You want to build her with high speed and survivability. Around 230+ speed with decent survivability, 3k+ DEF, 40k+ HP is recommended for Late Game+. 

Offensive stats do not matter as she does not do any damage. The best set to have on her is Relentless and Speed as her passive triggers every extra turn. Prioritize building the recommended stats on her. Do not build her in Relentless if you cannot achieve a decent number of recommended stats. Full Speed set is recommended if you cannot achieve the stats in Relentless.

If you are using her in a non-unkillable CB team, build her in Lifesteal instead. Keep the focus on the defensive stats for the CB level you are hitting (3k+ Def for NM, 4k+ Def for UNM) and the speed you need for your CB team. There are many types of CB teams where Doompriest can fit in. Generally her main role will be to cleanse the affinity debuff and stun the CB places on your team. To do that, she needs to be tuned to take her turn right after the CB so she can cleanse all the debuffs the CB places on your team immediately. This usually means she has to be fastest but it is not always the case. Always check your speed tune is a Clan Boss calculator to make sure she takes her turn right after the CB goes.

Glove: HP%/Def%
Chest: HP%/Def%
Boots: Speed
Ring: HP/Def
Amulet: HP/Def
Banner: HP/Def
data.label: Gear and stats

data.desc:
Ice Golem 20

In Ice Golem, Doompriest’s utility is the constant heal she provides and cleanse to remove Freeze and Decrease Def from your team. She can also place Increase Atk on your team if you have ATK based champion in your team for added damage. She is weak affinity for this dungeon level. However, Doompriest is tanky enough to withstand most nukes in this dungeon

This video showcases an example of an Ice Golem 20 team. 

Doompriest provides the utility mentioned above. 
Stag Knight provide AOE Def Down and ATK Down for further damage reduction and speeding up the runs. 
Dark Elhain is a damage dealer that can utilize her passive to convert the Freeze debuff into damage on the boss stage. 
Fenax is also a damage dealer with added utility to kill off the minions and block revive. 
Scyl provides additional support through passive healing, CC, and backup resurrection if things go South. 

https://youtu.be/fi_DChkN-M0

On the next page we wil be covering her in Dragon 20 setting and with Doom Tower bosses
data.label: Notes:

data.desc:
Dragon 20

In the Dragon dungeon, Doompriest provides the same utility with the constant healing and cleanse to remove Decrease Def debuffs on the Waves and Poisons from the Dragon. She can also place Increase Atk on your team if you have an ATK based champion on your team for additional damage. 

This video showcases an example of a Dragon 20 team. 

Doompriest provides the utility mentioned above. 
Zargala places AOE Def Down and deal damage for faster clears.
